casebody.data:
Russell MARKS, Petitioner-Appellant, v. Warden Jose VASQUEZ, Respondent-Appellee. No. 05-15708

Non-Argument Calendar.

United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit. March 15, 2006. Russell Bradley Marks, Marianna, FL, pro se. Amy Lee Copeland, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Savannah, GA, for Respondent-Appellee. Before TJOFLAT, DUBINA and HULL, Circuit Judges. PER CURIAM:

On April 16, 1993, the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri, having accepted petitioner’s plea of guilty to one count of conspiracy to distribute cocaine, in violation of 21 U.S.C. § 846, and one count of conspiracy to launder money, in violation of 18 U.S.C. § 371, sentenced petitioner to prison for life.1 After unsuccessfully exhausting his remedies on direct appeal from his conviction, and under 28 U.S.C. § 2255 and Fed. R.Crim.P. 36, he petitioned the district court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2241, for a writ of habeas corpus vacating his sentence and conviction.2

On August 15, 2005, after considering the Warden’s response and petitioner’s submissions, the district court on August 15, 2005, entered an order denying the petition. Petitioner now appeals.

We find no merit in this appeal. The district court’s order of August 15 constitutes a proper application of the law to the allegations of the petition.

AFFIRMED.

. The court's judgment indicates that petitioner was sentenced to "a total term life.” We assume that the court sentenced petitioner to concurrent terms of life imprisonment on the § 846 count and five years on the § 371 count.

. Petitioner filed the petition in the Southern District of Georgia because he was incarcerated in Georgia at the time.
